reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reviewed during alpha!

Despite many features yet unimplimented, Rising World is already an engrossing game in the vein of Minecraft.  Make no mistake, this is a Minecraft derivitive.  However, it containes significant improvements (other than graphical) and new ideas to recommend it over the older (and simpler) game.

I will postpone a full review until more content is added. In the meantime, there are two points to hightlight: First, this game is currently in alpha stage and likely will be for several more months (01/16 right now).  Development has been at a slow but steady pace.  While this is somewhat of a detriment, it is evidence of a don't release until we're ready to" attitude amongst development staff.  Second
date: the developers have been VERY responsive to player feedback and maintain a constant presence on the discussion board.  It's very telling that there is a developer comment in almost every thread.\n\nConclusion: It's too early.  If you liked Minecraft
recommended: you'll probably enjoy playing this right now
hoursPlayed: but it still has a ways to go before broader appeal.  This game has a ton of potential within the genre.\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite all of the slack this game gets, I love it! It's one of the best sandbox games I've played, but there is room for improvement. The new farming system really helps, but there is a lack of ranged weapons; usually resulting in me being slain by a bear! Character customization should be added some how, so you can cover up your players bald head!
Is it worth the £10.99 i payed for it?
Yes! The survival aspect is brilliant, the building system is amazing too I would deffinately recommend this game to people looking to have a laugh with their mates, or to record a let's paly on!
I can really see this game going somwhere in the near future! 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shows great promise. There are some glitches here and there and many features are missing, but from version 0.51 I expected 51% of the content - if this is 51% of the content, I expect something really great from this title.

What works:
Chopping trees, collecting stone, crafting components and assembling tools
You can build a wall of wood, marble etc
Build prison with bars and grates.
Run around and explore.

What does not:
Multiplayer - it's technically operational, but woe upon you shall you try it. As many forum comments state, whatever you build will be destroyed. If there was a way around it - perhaps give each player individual region - or ability to claim one region per player, where nobody else can do any modification? It is horrible to build up your castle to see it ruined two days later.

Early Access Review

Rising World is still in alpha phase and has a plethora of bugs and glithes, as does every alpha.

Pros:

-Great crafting system
-Phenominal tree falling animations and debris
-Good preformance (for me at least)
-No crashes thus far
-Awesome Poster" feature
-Pretty good graphics

Cons:

-Glitches/bugs

-Imbecile AI
-Some wierd sounds (such as the notorious "bird squawk")

For an alpha
date: I'd rate this game an 7/10. Keep up the good work

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a great game and I highly recommend it especially if you are new to Survival games. There is a passive mode for players who dont want to experience the violence from wilderness animals (single player only). The game has great potential and can be played in multiplayer as well. I havent played on a public server yet but we have a LAN server here at home that 3 of us play on. Hosting a server is a bit complicated at the moment but Im sure will be fixed eventually. There are also server hosting sites that support the game. Theres still some bugs but thats to be expected with any EA game. The game runs on windows 7-10 fine, not sure about anything else though. But despite the bugs, you could basicly build a whole city with some interesting geometry and then mine the ground underneath you. Supposedly there is a hell if you mine that far but i havent yet.
I've played many open world survivals and this one reaches out to me.  The game is built in Java so make sure thats up to date. This has good points and bad but Java being good for multiplayer and mods.
Good job team and keep up the good work.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reviewed during alpha!

Despite many features yet unimplimented, Rising World is already an engrossing game in the vein of Minecraft.  Make no mistake, this is a Minecraft derivitive.  However, it containes significant improvements (other than graphical) and new ideas to recommend it over the older (and simpler) game.

I will postpone a full review until more content is added. In the meantime, there are two points to hightlight: First, this game is currently in alpha stage and likely will be for several more months (01/16 right now).  Development has been at a slow but steady pace.  While this is somewhat of a detriment, it is evidence of a don't release until we're ready to" attitude amongst development staff.  Second
date: the developers have been VERY responsive to player feedback and maintain a constant presence on the discussion board.  It's very telling that there is a developer comment in almost every thread.\n\nConclusion: It's too early.  If you liked Minecraft
recommended: you'll probably enjoy playing this right now
hoursPlayed: but it still has a ways to go before broader appeal.  This game has a ton of potential within the genre.\n"
voteText: January 14

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has potential, I'll give it that! It just isn't up my alley currently as I have other games to play. It's in alpha right now so I really have nothing bad to say about it as it will probably be fixed in future updates (i.e. thirst meter exists and there's no water in the game yet.)

I'd probably like it more than Minecraft because it's slightly more advanced when it comes to gameplay. Resources are harder to get, torches need holders to be placed, you actually have to create placeable blocks with collected ore, etc. I will say that your guy can climb mountains like nobody's business!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I believe I've found a game for myself and those close to me to enjoy together.

The game looks nice. And it plays well.

The building at first, seems limited, but once you begin to build crafting benches and stations, the possibilites explode. There are many cool tools, and items to build.

There are a few things that would completely satisfy me with this game:

1. Water and ice.

2. Weather.

3. Enemies.

4. Birds

5. Treasure

6. Abandoned towns

Other than that, this is a very solid builder. It's very relaxing. My wife just watched me play for a bit, and now she's determined to buy herself a copy. Then, I'm going to recommend that my close gaming friends buy it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhenever my curiosity gets the best of me and I end up spending money on an Early Access game, I'm always a bit worried. Too many unfinished games of this kind have left a bad taste in my mouth over the years, some even after they  were finished". Therefore
date: Rising World proved a pleasant surprise. Make no mistake
recommended: the game is lacking in quite a few areas and bears clear indicators of being far from finished. But that's actually part of what excites me about it. Because it has immense amounts of potential
hoursPlayed: and is already a truly enjoyable game I can easily see myself investing WAY too much time in. If you like survival building games and don't mind Early Access
voteText: Rising World is well worth your buck
helpfulPercent: although in its current stage
votesHelpful: it might be a bit tedious in the long run. But if the developers pull through and keep making the game it seems like they want to make
votesTotal: I think it'll end up being a damn good investement."

I believe I've found a game for myself and those close to me to enjoy together.

The building at first, seems limited, but once you begin to build crafting benches and stations, the possibilites explode. There are many cool tools, and items to build.

There are a few things that would completely satisfy me with this game:

2. Weather.

5. Treasure

6. Abandoned towns

Other than that, this is a very solid builder. It's very relaxing. My wife just watched me play for a bit, and now she's determined to buy herself a copy. Then, I'm going to recommend that my close gaming friends buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After over ten hours, I'm truly impressed with this game.

For the first few hours, the game felt very similar to Minecraft for me, except with much improved graphics. I cut down trees, killed pigs, built a house, and went mining. Later in the game, I started exploring farming and all the furnitrure items I could create.

This game is focused mainly on BUILDING. The survival aspects aren't truly there yet. At the moment there aren't any enemies besides bears. The world feels more friendly this way, but building shelters feels a little pointless. Building is hella fun though. It's like Minecraft but the graphics make it completely different in it's own way. There are many different textured blocks as well.

Many glitches right now, but the dev is very active in the forums and is obviously working hard on the game. Watch some videos of this game, and if it looks interesting, I highly reccomend it.

Pros:
+ Graphics
+ Building Mechanics
+ Destructible environment
+ Tree cutting
+ Farming
+ Cooking and Smelting functions
+ Multiplayer
+ Very active dev team

Cons
- Glitches
- No threatening enemies
- Survival aspect is very easy as there is plenty of food everywhere.
- Not very in depth (yet).
- VERY easy to get lost at beginning.

7/10 at the moment, but the future holds so much potential for this game. Developer is awesome :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Screenshots and vids I saw of this game looked great. Concept for the game looked great. Did my research to make sure my rigs could handle the game and exceeded min specs by a mile on both my older, upgraded rig and my new custom built high end rig.

Nothing but Fatal Errors when attempting to launch the game. GPU's and CPU's on both rigs well above min specs AND recommended specs, Java JRE latest version. Yet Java issue after Java issue . I know I can't run Chrome. But the only browser I could set Steam to that even loaded the game for log in before it crashed again was IE 11. And I will not risk my PC' security on that piece of crap browser for even the mos epic game.

Seemed like a great game. Guess I will never know. Uninstalling and requesting a refund in the next 2 minutes.

May run great for some, I see lots of great looking stuff posted. But I am not risking that whatever is causing the Fatal Error after Fatal Error on Windows 7 and Windows 10 rigs will be fixed.

I can't speak to the game's quality, Just that it sucks not being able to even give it a try due to the list of errors encountered. :(
Will likely rebuy once I am sure it's not  a custom settings and config conflict with my rigs. I can't chage those settings, I need them for what I do for work. :(

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
Not recommended - Just paid £10.99 for a shortcut to the Java website. Excellent.

EDITED REVIEW:
Having tried various things (deleting and reinstalling the game, updating Java, uninstalling all versions of Java and then reinstalling the latest 32 bit and 64 bit versions of Java (both separately and together) and a few PC restarts) the game now runs. Whilst I'm happy it now runs it was certainly frustrating to have to go through any of that just to get it to run. I'm probably a little too early to yet give a proper review of the game but wanted to update my review out of fairness to the developer now that I've at least got a game to review.

From the bit I have played so far it seems quite promising but is certainly a bit glitchy (dying from falling less than a metre and randomly popping through the roof of a cave straight on to the floor above) but that isn't too much of an issue considering it is in early access so the usual suggestion apply; don't buy it yet unless you're aware that this is not a finished/polished/bug-free game yet and are happy with that. There seems to be enough here to have some fun with but also enough glitchiness with the physics as to cause a fair amount of frustration. I may change my review to recommended in the future but at the moment, with the kerfuffle of trying to get it to even launch and the current level of completion, I don't think I can recommend it just yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I never liked the look of Minecraft - too blocky for me ... why have a 21st century PC with HD textures when you play an 80's looking game ... I guess it must have been all about gameplay and creation.

Where Minecraft fell down (badly in my opinion) Rising World takes over. The choice of textures and shapes means you can create some really eye catching structures and not a jagged pixelated mess either.

The server files are released to the public from day one (always good when you want to build a community orientated server) and the developers are down to earth and helpful, taking on board feedback and ideas to add to the game's roadmap.

The game supports LUA scripts that enable hosts and admins to customise the server they and the players want.
Features such as area protection give players the chance to carry on building without the risk of losing their creation to a griefer - the scourge of many a game.

In its current form - I would give the game an 8/10 even with a few bugs as it's in early alpha.

I've had a server running for the past week and enjoy seeing what players come up with in their creations.

Just to add that there are some features I haven't seen in other games - such as being able to upload an image (to use as a poster) in-game. Being able to fully rotate alot of the objects enabling more and more possibilities when constructing a building or area.A piano in-game that you can play and hear others playing. Things like the sound of your footsteps on stone, soil and metal and the little details that have been added to make it more immersive.

I usually only play first person shooters and military sims - but this game is a breath of fresh air. It is probably in the same genre as The Forest and Rust but offers alot more content creation ability. I look forward to seeing how the game evolves over the coming months and recommend it to anyone that wants to try something a little different.

Our server will run for as long as the game develops <plug> (named V for Victory") </plug> and I look forward to spending more hours in Rising World. Visit their website @ https://www.rising-world.net - or grab the game from Steam."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is one of the more interesting sandbox/survival games I have played.  The world is beautiful. The cavern systems are very interesting and creepy, and while digging mines, sometimes you find them by accident.  The world terrain is very very deep.  They even put in a hell at the bottom where you see rivers and lakes of molten lava and islands of hellstone spires.  The building is very easy, and there are a lot of block material options.  All-in-all it is a great start!

It is very early  in development, and I am sure there is still a lot to be added; however, the developers are very open to Lua scripting and mods.  I have been asking them a ton of questions about their Lua API and they have answered every question very quickly.  They are about the nicest development team that you will ever meet!  I love their concepts and I really hope this game keeps going, because it is going to be one of the best!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can't begin to explain how much I love this game, the second I started playing I was hooked. At first I didn't understand the controls that well, but once I understood how it worked (I am a minecraft fanatic, just really used to those controls), I couldn't stop playing. The vast open worlds for exploring are beautiful, and the animals all about the place is great. Theres also food everywhere, so it's hard to starve. Also, the cave systems... oh man, so realistic looking. Looking over ledges in caves gives me chills because of my fear of heights. Also the torch in hand light system is pretty sick too. All in all, I give this game a 5/5 stars, even for an early alpha game with plenty of features to come!

P.S. I like how you can eat an entire slab of ribs in one bite :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rising World is the perfect game if you like building things.  It can be compared to Minecraft, only Rising World is much more modern and doesn't have the blocky graphics.  The physics are very realistic. Grass that waves in the wind, smoke (from furnace, fire etc) doesn't move through blocks, trees actually fall over when you cut them down.
I really think this game has the potential to become very big, once it's finished.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game has a lot of potential. The biggest problem right now is how long it takes for metal to be smelted. The cooking is just fine where it's at. One thing i would like to see in this game, is better mining tools (unless that is where the crafting table tier II comes in) that can get through mining just a little bit quicker. Though this may be an alpha, they are doing a good job with where they are at now; a good pace for more additions to their game, variety of decorations for buildings, and a very big map to make some insane structures. This game could be big when it comes out of alpha.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This reminds me of Runescape to be honest. For those who haven't heard of it, it's a MMO where you mine, chop wood, do quests, cook, farming, and lots of other skills. The goal was to reach level 100 and you're username would be on the leaderboard.

This is also reminds me of Minecraft with the sandbox, open world feeling. But Rising world takes it a step further will amazing graphics for it being only in Early Access"

The control are a bit weird
recommended: but really every game will be that way. You can change the shortcut keys (Such as your inventory to the E key just like in Minecraft; you can do this in the settings)\n\nThere are bugs
hoursPlayed: such as trees flying away if it lands on you and you're on the side of a hill. Logs will float once in awhile in the air for no reason. Could use a cleaner and slimmer interface for the main menu and settings dialog.\n\nThe support forums is mixed with German and English users. There is a Wiki
voteText: but not filled with all the needed info
helpfulPercent:
perhaps due to this game being in Early Access still.

I would highly suggest this game if you have previous experience with Minecraft and want some real world graphics. But I warn you there are bugs of course. But the main functions work just fine.

Long as the team continues to add updates
votesHelpful: and perhaps doing it more often in short updates
votesTotal: that may show more activity to the community and keep our hopes up. :)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This early access title is FANTASTIC!
Great graphics and sounds, great atmosphere in the world, amazing building opportunities!
I can't wait to see how this evolves, because it's awesome already!

One thing I think the developers should do is mention on the product page that it's possible for you to build whatever you like out of wood planks and beams. I don't remember seeing this information on the product page when I bought the game (unless I missed it). I bought it right away, but having that info on the product page would have definitely sealed the deal instantly for me. It's a really really amazing feature and should be publicised in my opinion.

This game is going to be epic when it's finished 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First Impressions:

I was immediately impressed with the visuals as everything looked amazing and lifelike.  I wasn't able to find any lakes or water unfortunately, nor is the collision detection and AI pathing smooth just yet.  Cows when hit, for example, walk a few steps, stop, turn, walk a few steps, stop, walk a few more, etc.  There's plenty to craft at the present time, though some of the items don't seem to require materials (I'm assuming costs will be added later as more raw resources make their way into the game, but I'm guessing).  All in all, a positive recommend considering the fifteen dollar price tag.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First 30 minutes of gameplay
> Menu appears
> Create an account with my name, what? no problem with the name? whoa first time in my life that this occurs ... GOTY!
> Settings, put everything in the maximum
> Create a new world
> Jokes appear while the world is created
> in the game ... it looks beautiful but the fps is low (23fps)
> Settings again, disables all
> The graphics remains the same, but now the fps is 52
> Cut a tree, lose mouse control, walk a little, lose control again, kill a pig, again the mouse goes crazy, walk a little more
> See rocks, walk up to them
> Falls into a cave, break an leg
> Digs up, makes a torch
> Back to the cave, explore, find nothing
> Out again, walk away, lose mouse control several times, suddenly pass trought the ground
> See strange things, the game freezes, ctrl+alt+del! all pc is slow !!
> Decides to wait for the final version

Graphics 8/10
Sound 7/10
Gameplay 5/10
nonsense 15/10
bugs 20/10

final note 4/20

Did you see the joke?

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBien qu'étant une version Alpha, Rising World est un jeu très prometteur. Ayant joué déjà quelques heures, j'ai rencontré que très peu de bugs (Impossibilité de monter dans une échelle, tombé dans le ''néant''). Certains objets sont difficile à placer (l'échelle par exemple), d'autres trop facile à acquérir. Pour l'instant je qualifierait ce jeux de sandbox-construction plutôt qu'un jeux de survie. Je suis impatient de découvrir vers quelle direction les concepteurs du jeu se dirigeront. Nice game! Keep on the good work :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is a great concept. It is the kind of game that I have wanted for a long time. There are still some minor bugs in the game that can be quite annoying, but is overall a good game. There is some obvious room for improvement, but is very very promising so long as it continues to have support and the developers continue to actively work on it.

I've only fallen out of the world once, and it sucked mostly because I lost some pretty valuable stuff. It was not that difficult to recover from the loss, though.

I also got my friends to get this game and they seem to enjoy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Put aside that this game is early release and there is not a lot of content for the exception of gathering food, mining and building structers that serve no purpose I think this game is a good concept and is pretty decent but it has many bugs that make game play extremely Fustratiing and unfriendly.

On a scale from 1 to 10, 10 being the best I give this game a 4.

I experienced more stablity when playing in single mode but everytime I played Multiplayer I constantly get booted.

Very frequently falling below terrain. Some times for no apparent reason, some times when cutting down trees tree will fall on top of your head and knock you below the terrain and in all cases you end up dead.

Also when I set home point for respawn after death it never works and when I click the respawn it spawns me with in the terrain just to be stuck and if there is no one on the server to help you get out you are stuck indifferently and once again end up dead just to repeat it all over again and end up having to just leave the server and try again on another server and experience the same things.

I also had trouble with the storage chests. I experienced large numbers of items disapearing in a few different situations. Some times when moving items from my person to the chest using a click and drag method some stacks would move successfully where some would not and just disappear, not in your inventory and not on the ground.

I also tried bouble clicking items to move them from personal inventory to the storage chest and just like the click and drag method I got the same results, some successfully moving and some just vanishing into thin air. And I also had stacks of items vanish when trying to move them from the storage chest to my person.

Also getting lots of Java errors and my java is up to date, not sure what the java errors areall about.

All in all as of now I would not suggest spending your hard earned money on this game until it is fully realsed and the bugs are worked out of it, good concept and will probably be good in the future if the Dev puts his mind to fixing issues and adds more content. I don't see updates with much new content, dev seems a bit lazy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had the game for 6 months. There have been many updates (according to the amount of downloads). I tried it at the start and found it awful.

The physics are laughable. I didn't get too much into the crafting side because the appearance and physics were so bad that I wasn't prepared to play it.

I just decided to try it again, after seemingly many updates, and found it hardly different to before. Maybe the graphics have improved - not really sure, but I still find them a low standard. On top of that, the physics doesn't appear to have changed at all. I would prefer a refund, but it's too late now, and I made the mistake of thinking it would get better within a few months.

Not recommended at all.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAwesome Game! Now I must mention, make sure you have Java 64 bit installed BEFORE downloading this game, as many people seemed to have difficulty starting it up. If you happen to accidentally download it without Java already installed I'd recommend deleting Rising World from your computer (e.g. delete from steam library) install java, then redownload the game. Something I want to tell the developers- man, this game would be so awesome if there was a slight horror element added to it. If I could have my way I'd have it to the point where at night you could barely see past your torchlight and monsters ran up on you very quickly and out of nowhere. I'd also add spooky atmospheric noises once night falls, along with terrifyingly loud noises once a monster has attacked you. Although I'd pay $100 for that to be implemented, you guys have done so well so far I'd recommend just sticking to your instinct and follow your goal of whatever you wanted Rising World to be. Keep up the fantastic work, you guys definitely have something special here.
voteText: 6 of 16 people (38%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to say I'm quite impressed so far. It reminds me of a mix of Minecraft, Rust, and Space Engineers (the mining/collection/control aspect). Beautiful graphics and I really like the night vision mode! I'm not sure if thats an early feature that will go away or not... but its nice being able to mine without torches!

Very unfinished at this point, you can only collect wood and stone, but any items you need that aren't craftable... you can just... GET. Done! It's got a lot of cool crafting possibilities that are all vanilla, which you would require a dozen minecraft mods to match. Pretty slick!

This is basically the 'real' looking survival mining game I've been waiting for! I can't wait to see what happens next!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nObviously VERY early days but i thought id write a quick first impression while a Java problem is sorted out stopping some of us playing.  Early stages but im liking the general ideas of this game not to mention the fact that for me personally this is ideal for someone that enjoys working at their own pace on a survival/sandbox sort of game, a casual experience. So far there are a few basic options in creating your own worlds including flat worlds, cave orientated worlds or forest/dense worlds. This is going to be an interesting development for me and hopefully if all goes well and problems ironed out this could turn out to be a very nice tidy game. I will write another review once ive sunk my teeth into it properly for a good day or so. For those unsure of purchasing, maybe best to hold on tight for now and keep up with other peoples reviews as early access purchases always come with a risk. Money comes and goes (and i appreciate its harder for some people to make) but for this price i had to personally take the chance and show my support. Only time will tell like all early access games. :)) Right, now to try and load it up again lol

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI have a thing for early access games so Rising World seemed like it would be interesting.  I didn't know it was possible to make something even more boring than Minecraft.  Sure the environment is more customizable than Minecraft but its only slightly so you eventually see the same angles over and over again.  Its hard to figure out how you need to build your mine shaft so you can climb back out of it.  Overall good promise just needs more polish to the movement it doesn't feel very responsive.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is a pain in the a** so start the launch, i guess i got lucky and downloaded the write Java update. But after that i was a little let down, thinking i might be able to play this game. So i reset my PC and tried to launch the game and it worked fine and dandy. The title screen like minecraft with your options on the left, so when your logged in and ready to play, you make your world and jump right in. right away i find my first animal and kill it, i notice Pigs dont have food in them but this is in Alpha so i cant say i didnt exspect it to be done. so as im playing i find the crafting tab. and i was so sad at first. cause the menu has like 5 or 6 categories with 1 or 2 items in each, then i saw the workbench and was so releaved. So i made my underground house and made my workbench, and started to make a house... out of Plaster. and that worked fine and dandy. and i made all the crafting stations and a really big, nice house. So this is a really nice game, i dont regret buying this game. This game has HUGE potincial, and i cant wait to see the next update.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I regret I bought this game.
At first it was just the fact that I had to download a special version of Java to play it.
Then it was the mediocre loading screen and menu graphics.
Then it was the horrible in game fps and voxel system that lets you fall through the map while mining.
And finally it was the boring, repetitive mountainous terrain with a much too limited veiwing distance.

At least the trees and grass look nice.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Can't even get a new world to load, it just crashes.  After searching, I discovered it seems to be a common problem.  The game has minimum graphics card requirements and doesn't handle any card well which doesn't match those requirements (i.e. it crashes).  Didn't see any mention of minimum requirements on the Steam store page.  Not cool for a game that is very appealing to little kids with parents that aren't really PC gamers and won't have the latest hardware.  Even more uncool that we probably won't get our money back.  Now we're stuck with a game we paid $15 for that we can't even play because we're not going to go spend a bunch more to get a graphics card that will work.

Refund please!?!?!?!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI had fun with this game . . . at first, then I started noticing it freezing and crashing whenever I wanted to use the menu interface to construct new things; then, it started crashing when I walked in certain areas of the map; finally, it started crashing for no reason after I built a castle. I uninstalled the game reinstalled the game, same issue was present. I created another world and the exact same thing happened in the exact same order: from the moment you start to build and craft your game is a ticking time bomb for a crash-fest. Please don't suggest it was my machine because I tried it on a different machine and the same results. I contacted Steam about a refund and they said no refund for early access games. Please contact the developer"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rising World adds new patches everytime with new stuff. What I want to know is when do you fix your glitches? I played the game and it reminds me of the time Minecraft had the same stuff. I fell through the graphics landed in Hell which is -830 Y axis.
If you buy the game press F3 for Location. In the top left hand corner is you X axis, Y axis , and  Z axis. My advise to the programmers is this is not funny! We pay for your game and get glitches!
How big did you make the map? Java is not ment for games and I will say it again! Break out the C language and fix it! Since your in your Alpha version and not in you prime... start paying for gaming testers! I would like people to know I do not lie about this.
System specs for this game should read as Follows.

i7 core  60 GB processing speed
Memory 164 GB
Vidoe card 80 GB processing speed
Shader set for 90

Might as well start with your parents vacant room for 8 super towers that cost you $148,000.00
Even then maybe you can run their game properly.

Key word for designers is smaller maps  X axis 148 , Y axis 54, Z axis 148. I would think someone would wise up.
If we need to explore a new content load a new map with the same dimisions.  Other wise give up we don't need another Minecraft correction!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rising World is another voxelbased indiependently developed open-world survival game like minecaft, but unfortunealy it shares a lot of problem with minecraft too.Like the very bugs that pleauged minecraft in the earlier version and some that pleauge the game to this day,like the various grafic and world glitches,but you probably have to expect this from a java based game since java is not the most stable engine ever created.But while rising world shares a lot with minecraft in the technial department,it does not succed with it's gameplay,
It does not have a very involved ground structure, in minecraft the formula goes like this: Spawn in world,punch tree,make wood out of tree,start to build,dig hole in ground,wait through the night, punch more trees, look through wiki, build tools... continue until you have achived your goal of building a six metre high golden ♥♥♥♥ and balls
,but here it isn't as fun as in minecraft since it lags the real sense of progression.
You already start out with the tools,it isn't as difficult to do things and I simply had not fun with the game,it is too minecraft like,but it lags the features that minecraft so fun for most people,I give it a seven out of twenty. 7/20

reviewText:
Early Access Review

10/10: Worth any penny of the price!

For a programme labelled as Alpha, I found it surprisingly stable and already rich in features. In several dozens of hours of playing I did not have a single crash and only one (non-blocking) bug with mouse capture in full screen, dependent on my multi-monitor setup.

The number of items which can be crafted is already quite large (there is even a piano you can actually play!) and only a fraction of them are 'blocky' (in fact, for a voxel game, the general appearance is very far from obviously 'blocky').

Implemented functions/features include: mining, processing of stone and ore into resources, gathering food, hunting, farming and harvesting of a number of crops, including trees for wood resources (no herding, though), terraforming, and of course crafting. Practically anything there is in the world can be acted upon and/or modified/removed/destroyed.

The graphics are very well engineered: trees, grass, stone, ore veins within stone, all looks quite realistic,even after modifying them. The game is also not very hungry in specs: with my oldish ATI HD 5770, the tens of thousands of grass blades and of landscape blocks are rendered with no noticeable impact on the fluidity of movement.

Of course, there are things not implemented yet, as it can be expected in an Alpha: the biggest limit is probably in survival. There is a survival mode, but the only dangers you risk to meet are starving and falling from too high. The crafting tree is relatively wide (a fair number of item to make) but short: only one or two steps from the raw resource(s) to the finished product. There is no water, nor weather or seasons. There are commands for displaying a clock and a compass, but they do nothing at the moment. I did fall in a hole in the ground and broke a bone: there seems to be no way of mending it, nor does it affect character abilities in any way. I expected most of the limitation to be overcome as the programme evolves (and, yes, it does evolve).

Some design choices might be questionable; primarily, the impossibility to move objects once placed in the world, even objects which in the 'real world' work because they can be moved, like chairs. Once placed, anything can only be destroyed and rebuilt elsewhere (NOT TRUE: see edit below!).

These limitations notwithstanding, the game is fully enjoyable and very mature for an Alpha (and possibly not only for an Alpha). I already spent on it more hours than I expected and now I know I will spend many many more, even before further updates will add new features.

EDIT: I was wrong! It IS possible to un-place placed objects, getting them back and placing them elsewhere. Another plus for RW!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I kind of like the idea of a more soft approach to the survival this game offers, but early access adopters beware: there be bugs!

Pros:
You are free to roam and build your own kingdom in the middle of the forest the way you see fit. No zombies or anything like that, just you and the local fauna.
Relaxing, not a hardcore survival game.
Devs are very responsive and willing to sort out your problems.
Cons:
Bugs, bugs and more bugs. Animals clipping through walls, light acts funny, etc.
Linux version suffers more severe bugs due to some libraries used.
Requires you to create yet another online account.
There isn't really all that much to do at the moment other than to build enormous sandcastles to compensate for your personal shortcomings so unless you are really into building stuff, the game might become boring after a while.
Controls, when it comes to finetuning the building process to make something nice, are not exactly the most intuitive and sometimes it is incredibly frustrating to get the pieces snap together the way you want them to.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game way back last year and didn't put many hours in it due to the lack of things to do at the time. Now after picking it back up, they have improved a lot. Tigers, Elephants, Giraffes, better land (used to be mountains on mountains, no flat land), and water. Obviously the game is still being worked on and I can't wait to see what they continue to add. I hope to see bows and arrows soon since I prefer fighting bears and tigers from affar. The building in this game is great. You can get so creative; From medival villages to modern houses. I do hope they also fix the cave system since it's literally a hole in the ground.

Pros: Constant updates, can be as creative as possible, arrange of animals, gorgeous game, caves are deep

Cons: Not many weapon choices, no durability on tools, planted sapplings don't grow that fast it at all (still waiting on my nursery to grow), water drops faster than food (watermelons and tomatos are your friends).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has the potential to be a Minecraft killer, if it plays it's cards right.

It is still early in development, so I reserve my criticisms.

I love the game so far and enjoy the development put forth. They're still laying the foundation to this game, but what I'm seeing for far is very encouraging.

[What I'm hoping to see, when the time is right...]

Once the core foundation of the game is complete, I would like to see the game or an available option for the game, for adventure and exploration. Meaning, I would like to be digging and discover bones, or ancient architectural artifacts, pyramids, obelisks, etc.
It would be cool to collect bones and if you have enough of the same type of animal, you could reconstruct a skeleton. Or find various artifacts that you can combine together to solve puzzles.

This may not be the direction they want to go.

I hope there is a mod for this theme though.
